senses.de: To note the similarity or dissimilarity between things or people.
senses.ex: Please compare these two dresses and tell me which one you like better.

Tips.title: Comparison Basis
Tips.description: Be clear on what basis items or people are compared; look for shared characteristics or purposes.
Tips.example: Compare the fuel efficiency of these cars, not their color.

Tips.title: Critical Thinking
Tips.description: Use comparing to analyze pros and cons or make informed decisions.
Tips.example: Compare the candidates' policies carefully before voting.

Tips.title: Objective vs. Subjective
Tips.description: Understand when comparison is based on facts (objective) or personal preference (subjective).
Tips.example: Comparing test scores is objective; comparing beauty is subjective.

senses.de: To be equivalent or identical to, or capable of being compared with.
senses.ex: Nothing can compare with a mother's love.

Tips.title: Equality in Comparison
Tips.description: Use 'compare with' when stating two things are on the same level or standard.
Tips.example: This wine compares favorably with expensive brands.

Tips.title: Unique Comparisons
Tips.description: Use 'beyond compare' for something so unique, it stands out among others.
Tips.example: Her singing talent is beyond compare.

Tips.title: Emotional Impact
Tips.description: Understand that some comparisons might carry emotional weight or imply strong preferences.
Tips.example: Nothing can compare to my grandmother's cooking.

senses.de: To regard or represent as analogous or similar; to liken.
senses.ex: He compared her eyes to stars.

Tips.title: Poetic Comparisons
Tips.description: Use 'compare to' to create vivid imagery or for artistic expression.
Tips.example: The poet compared her smile to the first rays of sunshine.

Tips.title: Metaphorical Usage
Tips.description: Understand that comparisons can be metaphorical, not literal.
Tips.example: Comparing life to a journey suggests many ups and downs.

Tips.title: Similarity Not Equality
Tips.description: Comparing implies similarity, not necessarily equality or identity.
Tips.example: He compared the twins' talents, noting their unique yet similar gifts.

Analyse.wordDefinition:
Analyse means to study or examine something closely and break it down into smaller parts to understand how it works, why it happens or how it affects something.

You would use analyse when you want to understand how something works, while you would use compare when you want to understand how two different things are the same or different.

Balance.wordDefinition:
Balance refers to finding an equilibrium or equal distribution of weight between two or more things. For example, balancing a scale means that both sides of the scale have an equal amount of weight.

This word is typically used when discussing physical objects or financial matters, such as balancing a bank account or balancing on one foot.

Balance is used when there is a need to achieve equal distribution of weight, while compare is used when there is a need to find similarities and differences between two things.

Check.wordDefinition:
Check means to verify or confirm something, while compare means to examine the similarities and differences between two or more things.

Check is applicable when you want to ensure accuracy, like checking your homework for errors or checking if you have all the items on a grocery list.

Collate.wordDefinition:
Collate means to gather and arrange information or data in a particular order or sequence while compare means to examine two or more things in order to observe their similarities and differences.

For example, if you have a large set of papers and you want to arrange them in a specific order, you would use collate.

Collate is used to organize and arrange information in a structured way, while compare is used to analyze and evaluate similarities and differences between different things or data sets.

Contrast.wordDefinition:
Contrast means to look at two or more things and find differences between them. For example, you might contrast two different kinds of ice cream to see which one is sweeter or has more chocolate chips.

However, you would use compare when you want to focus on similarities and contrast when you want to focus on differences.

Equate.wordDefinition:
Equate means to consider two things as being equal or of the same value or importance. For example, you can equate the value of two different currencies, or equate the importance of two different tasks.

Equations focus on similarities rather than differences, and imply that the two things being equated are equivalent in some way.

Compare is used when you want to talk about the differences and similarities between two or more things, while equate is used when you want to suggest that two things have the same value or importance.

Match.wordDefinition:
Match means to find something that is identical or very similar to something else. For example, you might match a sock to its pair.

Match is used when you want to find something that is identical or compatible with another thing.

Parallel.wordDefinition:
Parallel means to extend or run alongside something without intersecting it. It is applicable when you want to describe things that are similar in certain ways but do not necessarily have anything in common.

For example, you can say that two rivers are parallel, meaning that they flow side by side without mixing.

Compare is used when you want to find similarities and differences between things, while parallel is used when you want to describe things that are similar but not necessarily related.

quotes.Text: I'm just going to say it: I'm pro-guilt. Guilt is good. Guilt helps us stay on track because it's about our behavior. It occurs when we compare something we've done - or failed to do - with our personal values.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Brene Brown

quotes.Text: Let everyone try and find that as a result of daily prayer he adds something new to his life, something with which nothing can be compared.
quotes.Title: Indian Leader
quotes.Name: Mahatma Gandhi

quotes.Text: Property as compared with humanity, as compared with the red blood in the American people, must take second place, not first place.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Woodrow Wilson

quotes.Text: When you are content to be simply yourself and don't compare or compete, everybody will respect you.
quotes.Title: Chinese Philosopher
quotes.Name: Lao Tzu

quotes.Text: Those who have compared our life to a dream were right... we were sleeping wake, and waking sleep.
quotes.Title: French Philosopher
quotes.Name: Michel de Montaigne

quotes.Text: Personal interests have no importance compared to national interests.
quotes.Title: Pakistani Politician
quotes.Name: Shehbaz Sharif

quotes.Text: We're always compared to somebody in all walks of life, aren't we?
quotes.Title: English Musician
quotes.Name: Ed Skrein

quotes.Text: It's often said that life is strange. But compared to what?
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Steve Forbert

quotes.Text: Many world champions compare themselves to my father.
quotes.Title: German Driver
quotes.Name: Mick Schumacher

quotes.Text: I'm very staid compared to my students, actually.
quotes.Title: American Activist
quotes.Name: Kathy Acker
